security_audit.summary: The codebase is a legitimate MCP server development toolkit with evaluation capabilities. While it contains concerning capabilities like command execution and external network calls, these are necessary for its stated purpose of testing MCP servers. The main security consideration is that evaluation data is sent to Anthropic's API.

medium_findings.title: External API calls send evaluation data
medium_findings.description: All evaluation questions and tool responses are sent to Anthropic's Claude API. While this is necessary for the evaluation functionality, users should be aware that their data is transmitted externally.

medium_findings.title: Arbitrary command execution capability
medium_findings.description: The evaluation script can execute user-specified commands through the stdio transport mechanism. This is necessary for testing local MCP servers but could be misused.

low_findings.title: Environment variable propagation
low_findings.description: User-provided environment variables are passed to subprocesses without validation. This could potentially expose sensitive environment variables.

content.user_title: Build MCP servers for AI integration
content.value_statement: MCP servers enable Claude to interact with external services through well-designed tools. This guide provides complete implementation patterns for Python and TypeScript with evaluation frameworks.
limitations: Requires external API calls for evaluation
Command execution needed for stdio transport

prompt_templates.title: Basic MCP server

prompt_templates.title: Tool implementation
prompt_templates.scenario: Add a new tool to MCP server

output_examples.input: Create an MCP server for a weather API
output: Tool implementation for fetching current weather

best_practices: Use streamable HTTP transport for remote servers and stdio for local servers
Implement comprehensive API coverage with clear, action-oriented tool names
Add proper input validation using Zod (TypeScript) or Pydantic (Python)
Include structured output schemas to help clients process tool responses
anti_patterns: Avoid creating too many specialized workflow tools instead of comprehensive API coverage
Do not skip input validation or error handling for tool implementations
Never hardcode credentials or sensitive data in your MCP server code
Avoid creating tools that perform destructive operations without proper safeguards

faq.question: Which transport should I use for my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use streamable HTTP for remote servers that need to scale, and stdio for local servers running on the same machine as the client.

faq.question: How do I handle authentication in my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use environment variables for credentials and implement proper token refresh logic. Never hardcode API keys in your source code.

faq.question: Can I test my MCP server before deploying?
faq.answer: Yes, use the MCP Inspector tool with 'npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector' to test your server interactively.

faq.question: What programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: This guide covers TypeScript (recommended) and Python implementations using the official MCP SDKs.

faq.question: How do I create evaluations for my MCP server?
faq.answer: Create an XML file with question-answer pairs that test realistic use cases. Each question should require multiple tool calls.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using the evaluation framework?
faq.answer: Evaluation questions and answers are sent to Anthropic's API for processing. Do not include sensitive data in your evaluations.
